title: 108_hr745
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2003" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff. Job dissatisfaction and overtime work contribute to nurses leaving the profession. The Comptroller General of the United States reported that health care providers rely on mandatory overtime, leading to nurse fatigue and compromising patient safety. Limiting mandatory overtime will ensure public safety, quality care, and nurse retention. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider Agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. A provider of services is prohibited from mandatory overtime, except as provided in the subsection. A provider of services is restricted from requiring nurses to work beyond specified limits, including not exceeding 12 hours in a 24-hour period or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period. Exceptions apply during declared states of emergency for providing emergency medical services to the community. During declared states of emergency, a nurse can only be required to work beyond specified limits if the provider has tried to fill staffing needs through alternative means and the work requirement ends when the state of emergency ends. During declared states of emergency, a nurse can file a complaint with the Secretary against a provider of services who violates the provisions of this subsection, and the Secretary will investigate and take actions if a violation is found. During declared states of emergency, a nurse can file a complaint with the Secretary against a provider of services for violations. The Secretary will investigate and may seek civil money penalties. Providers must not penalize or discriminate against nurses who refuse mandatory overtime or report violations. During declared states of emergency, nurses can report violations of regulations to regulatory agencies, accreditation bodies, or provider management. They can also participate in investigations or proceedings related to the violations and discuss them with colleagues or healthcare professional associations. During declared states of emergency, nurses can report violations of regulations to regulatory agencies, accreditation bodies, or provider management. They can also participate in investigations or proceedings related to the violations and discuss them with colleagues or healthcare professional associations. Providers of services are prohibited from retaliatory reporting against nurses who refuse to work mandatory overtime. Nurses are deemed to be acting in good faith if they believe the reported information is true and a violation has occurred or may occur. Each provider of services must conspicuously post notice requirements. Providers of services must post a sign specifying nurses' rights and the process for filing complaints. They are also required to regularly post nurse schedules in a conspicuous manner. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of the provisions related to nurse schedules. More severe penalties can be imposed for repeated violations. Penalty administration follows section 1128A guidelines. The Secretary can impose civil money penalties up to $10,000 for knowing violations related to nurse schedules, following section 1128A guidelines. The names of penalized providers and violations will be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. Penalties for providers under previous ownership will not be published after 1 year. The Secretary can impose civil money penalties up to $10,000 for knowing violations related to nurse schedules, following section 1128A guidelines. Penalties for providers under previous ownership will not be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website after the 1-year period. Nurses can voluntarily work more than specified hours as long as it aligns with professional standards. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked exceeding specified periods, with potential adverse consequences for refusal. The term 'nurse' refers to a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse, working in various healthcare settings like hospitals, outpatient departments, and home health agencies. Adverse consequences for nurses may include discharge, discipline, loss of promotion, or reporting to the State disciplinary agency. Overtime is defined as working beyond specified periods. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency. It excludes emergencies resulting from labor disputes or consistent understaffing in the healthcare industry. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to recognized professional standards for nurses. The amendments will take effect 1 year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing patient care. The study will consider various factors such as provider type, department, duties, and shifts. A report must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the study conducted regarding appropriate standards for maximum work hours. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on overtime practices in federally operated medical facilities for nurses. The term "federally operated medical facilities" includes hospitals, clinics, and home health care facilities run by government departments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report to Congress within 6 months with recommendations for overtime policies for nurses in these facilities.
